Three minors under the age of 15 were questioned and, according to the authorities, one of them admitted to lighting an object that sparked the blaze inside Tehtaan kentta.
An investigation is ongoing but in Finland, children under 15 are not criminally liable.
There is no clarity about why the vandalism occurred. It is unclear, for example, if it was motivated by Hakaâ€™s relegation or something else entirely. What is certain is that Haka cannot use their stadium for the time being. One look at the extent of the blaze (above) and the smouldering aftermath helps explain why.
Modest though their surroundings might be (Tehtaan kentta has a capacity of just 3,500, and Valkeakoski a population of 21,000), Haka are a famous footballing brand in Finland. They have nine league titles to their name, along with 12 Finnish Cups â€” only one club, Helsinkiâ€™s HJK, have won more in either competition. And the reassuring part of an unhappy story is that the sport is coming together to help them rebuild.
How are they rebuilding the club?
Haka, whose artificial pitch was also damaged by the fire, launched an immediate fundraising appeal with quick results. Finnish players based domestically and elsewhere in Europe have donated match shirts for an auction. One came from a UEFA Conference League tie involving Kuopion Palloseura, who beat Haka twice last season, results that played a big part in their relegation from the Veikkausliiga.
